T1.label: Cost Leader Resilience
T1.description: Fortescue Ltd executes on growth strategy; earnings accelerate
T1.plain_english: Fortescue's sub-US$19/wmt C1 cost position ensures profitability even at iron ore prices of US$85-95/t. Record shipments, operational discipline, and balance sheet strength sustain dividends and cash returns through a downcycle. The stock holds value as a cash flow machine even if iron ore declines moderately.
T1.what_to_watch: Next earnings result and forward guidance.
T1.upside: Material re-rating if execution surprises to the upside.
T1.risk_plain: If growth disappoints, this narrative weakens.

T2.label: Iron Ore Structural Decline
T2.description: Fortescue Ltd delivers steady-state results; valuation holds
T2.plain_english: China has passed peak steel production (2020). Property accounts for ~50% of steel demand and is in structural decline. Electric arc furnace (EAF) steelmaking rises to 18% by the 2030s, reducing blast furnace iron ore demand. Simandou delivers 120 Mtpa of high-grade ore by 2030, displacing FMG's lower-grade product. Iron ore falls below US$80/t, compressing FMG earnings by 40%+.
T2.risk_plain: If the base case is already priced in, limited upside from here.

T3.label: Green Energy Pivot Succeeds
T3.description: Fortescue Ltd faces headwinds; earnings or multiples compress
T3.plain_english: Fortescue Energy delivers a viable green business: green iron metal technology achieves commercial scale, hydrogen partnerships (TES) succeed, and copper exploration (Alta in Peru) provides diversification. The Energy division transitions from a capital sink to a profit contributor.
T3.what_to_watch: Cost pressures, competitive threats, or macro headwinds.
T3.upside: See research report for upside scenario detail.
T3.risk_plain: Material downside if multiple risks crystallise simultaneously.

T4.label: Forrest Governance & Capital Misallocation
T4.description: A structural shift changes the investment case for Fortescue Ltd
T4.plain_english: Andrew Forrest's ~36% shareholding and Executive Chairman role enables capital misallocation without effective board oversight. Green energy investments destroy shareholder value as Forrest pursues a personal legacy project. The "founder trap" prevents the company from optimising capital allocation for minority shareholders.
T4.what_to_watch: Industry disruption signals and regulatory changes.
T4.risk_plain: If disruption materialises, prior assumptions become invalid.

big_picture: Fortescue's Metals division is a world-class mining operation: record 198.4 Mt shipped at US$18.17/wmt C1 cost, generating 56% EBITDA margins. But the investment case is overwhelmed by structural headwinds. China has passed peak steel (2020), iron ore prices are forecast to decline to US$83-95/t by end-2026, Simandou will add 120 Mtpa of new supply, and the Energy division has written off US$150M+ on cancelled green hydrogen projects. Andrew Forrest's ~36% stake concentrates governance risk. The stock trades above consensus broker targets of A$18.58-19.86, making it one of the few ASX 50 stocks where the market is more bullish than analysts.
